snippet: A plan to move radioactive fuel to safer storage at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant is a critical step in a long decommissioning process that has already had serious setbacks.
abstract: Tokyo Electric Power Company is set to start delicate and risky task of using a crane to remove radioactive fuel assemblies from the pool at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, critical step in long decommissioning process that has already had serious setbacks; attempt underscores the potentially hazardous work that lies ahead at the plant, which was crippled by explosions and meltdowns in wake of Japan's 2011 earthquake and tsunami.

byline.contributor: Makiko Inoue and Hisako Ueno contributed reporting from Tokyo, and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.

lead_paragraph: A plan to move radioactive fuel to safer storage at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant is a critical step in a long decommissioning process that has already had serious setbacks.

headline.main: Removing Fuel Rods Poses New Risks at Crippled Nuclear Plant in Japan
headline.print_headline: Removing Fuel Rods Poses New Risks at Crippled Nuclear Plant in Japan
